question.title: find endianness of system in java

node.contents: Java is strictly big endian as far as I know. There's no way (and indeed no reason) to find out the endianness of the underlying architecture without invoking native code.

astNode.text: Java is strictly big endian as far as I know. There's no way (and indeed no reason) to find out the endianness of the underlying architecture without invoking native code.

node.contents: I think you're out of luck. The JVM shields you from such implementation specific details.

astNode.text: I think you're out of luck. The JVM shields you from such implementation specific details.

node.contents: Nitpick: doesn't this use of `union` trigger undefined behavior? I'd use a `char const *` into a `uint32_t` instead.

astNode.text: Nitpick: doesn't this use of `union` trigger undefined behavior? I'd use a `char const *` into a `uint32_t` instead.

node.contents: The only reason I can think of for wanting to know this is to create binary files for consumption by a non-Java application, or to build a compiler in Java, perhaps. Rather obscure.

astNode.text: The only reason I can think of for wanting to know this is to create binary files for consumption by a non-Java application, or to build a compiler in Java, perhaps. Rather obscure.

node.contents: assuming both macines has a wordlength of 1 byte. If my data is abcd, i will get it in form abcd from little machine and i have to store it as dcba.Am i correct?

astNode.text: assuming both macines has a wordlength of 1 byte. If my data is abcd, i will get it in form abcd from little machine and i have to store it as dcba.Am i correct?

node.contents: IF word length is 1 byte, there's no endianness at all. Your byte is your word. Complications only set in when you have multi-byte words, as you do in almost every system.

astNode.text: IF word length is 1 byte, there's no endianness at all. Your byte is your word. Complications only set in when you have multi-byte words, as you do in almost every system.

node.contents: but suppose i have data as abcd . When storint it in main memory little will store it as A at 100, B at101 ,c at 102,D at103 and big will store it as D at 100,C at 101,B at102,A at 103 .Am i correct?

astNode.text: but suppose i have data as abcd . When storint it in main memory little will store it as A at 100, B at101 ,c at 102,D at103 and big will store it as D at 100,C at 101,B at102,A at 103 .Am i correct?

elements.contents: int is_big_endian(void) { union { uint32_t i; char c[4]; } bint = {0x01020304}; return bint.c[0] == 1; }

node.contents: You still need to show you could do it, even if you shouldn't. I would say, look at how its done already should be a reasonable answer. Recently I had to create a custom scapegoat TreeMap which used `int` as a key and multiple values for that key and recycled all its nodes. Of course I copied good portions of code from TreeMap and kept the names the same as much as possible.

node.contents: You can't do this in pure Java without calling a library. This is because;

astNode.text: You can't do this in pure Java without calling a library. This is because;

node.contents:
• Java says you shouldn't care about such things if you can avoid it.
  • Java is relatively feature poor as a language and relies on its libraries to do a lot of things which might be a language feature in another language.
  • Most people don't distinguish between what the language does and what is a built in library because the distinction is rarely useful.
  • Byte code/virtual machine is not big endian or little endian as such, only real implementations are. ;)

astNode.text:
• Java says you shouldn't care about such things if you can avoid it.
  • Java is relatively feature poor as a language and relies on its libraries to do a lot of things which might be a language feature in another language.
  • Most people don't distinguish between what the language does and what is a built in library because the distinction is rarely useful.
  • Byte code/virtual machine is not big endian or little endian as such, only real implementations are. ;)

node.contents: Older libraries only support big endian (which most processors use, Intel being a notable exception) Newer libraries can be set one way or the other.

astNode.text: Older libraries only support big endian (which most processors use, Intel being a notable exception) Newer libraries can be set one way or the other.

node.contents: It is pretty rare that you need to know how to re-write built in functionality again, and if you did, you would read the code on how it is done already (even if you did know how it could be done)

astNode.text: It is pretty rare that you need to know how to re-write built in functionality again, and if you did, you would read the code on how it is done already (even if you did know how it could be done)

node.contents: I have seen many people redevelop built in functionality which is buggy, more difficult to use because it behave in unexpected ways and less performant than the built in libraries. It is quite possible to write something faster or more bespoke than what is in the JDK, but its very rarely useful to know how off the top of your head.

astNode.text: I have seen many people redevelop built in functionality which is buggy, more difficult to use because it behave in unexpected ways and less performant than the built in libraries. It is quite possible to write something faster or more bespoke than what is in the JDK, but its very rarely useful to know how off the top of your head.

node.contents: I do get these questions from time to time, and before answering the question I point out all the reasons you wouldn't do this. ;)

astNode.text: I do get these questions from time to time, and before answering the question I point out all the reasons you wouldn't do this. ;)

node.contents: On JVMs that have the sun.misc.Unsafe class and store an Unsafe singleton in a static instance variable named "theUnsafe", then the following approach can be used. I tested this successfully on the Oracle JVM and openjdk. The code works by writing a short (2 bytes) value of 1 to memory, and then reading the first byte.

astNode.text: On JVMs that have the sun.misc.Unsafe class and store an Unsafe singleton in a static instance variable named "theUnsafe", then the following approach can be used. I tested this successfully on the Oracle JVM and openjdk. The code works by writing a short (2 bytes) value of 1 to memory, and then reading the first byte.

elements.contents: import java.lang.reflect.Field; import sun.misc.Unsafe; public class Endianness { private static Unsafe getUnsafe() { Unsafe unsafe = null; try { Field f = sun.misc.Unsafe.class.getDeclaredField("theUnsafe"); f.setAccessible(true); unsafe = (Unsafe) f.get(null); } catch (Exception e) {} return unsafe; } public static void main(String[] args) { Unsafe unsafe = getUnsafe(); long address = unsafe.allocateMemory(2); short number = 1; unsafe.putShort(address, number); if (unsafe.getByte(address) == 0) System.out.println("Big Endian"); else System.out.println("Little Endian"); unsafe.freeMemory(address); } }

units.rawText: import java.lang.reflect.Field; import sun.misc.Unsafe; public class Endianness { private static Unsafe getUnsafe() { Unsafe unsafe = null; try { Field f = sun.misc.Unsafe.class.getDeclaredField("theUnsafe"); f.setAccessible(true); unsafe = (Unsafe) f.get(null); } catch (Exception e) {} return unsafe; } public static void main(String[] args) { Unsafe unsafe = getUnsafe(); long address = unsafe.allocateMemory(2); short number = 1; unsafe.putShort(address, number); if (unsafe.getByte(address) == 0) System.out.println("Big Endian"); else System.out.println("Little Endian"); unsafe.freeMemory(address); } }

node.contents: The JVM, and therefore Java, is strictly big-endian, regardless of the host platform.

astNode.text: The JVM, and therefore Java, is strictly big-endian, regardless of the host platform.

node.contents: However, in relation character encodings, it is possible to extract information about the system default encoding, which may have an endianness (in fact, it is likely to).

astNode.text: However, in relation character encodings, it is possible to extract information about the system default encoding, which may have an endianness (in fact, it is likely to).

node.contents: Would you hire someone who wrote their own (and potentially buggy) sort() method instead of using the tested, well understood built in one, if it did the job.

astNode.text: Would you hire someone who wrote their own (and potentially buggy) sort() method instead of using the tested, well understood built in one, if it did the job.

node.contents: I strongly doubt there is any other way to do this, actually. Java is designed to be platform-independent, so almost all of its methods will give you the same results on a big-endian or little-endian machine.

astNode.text: I strongly doubt there is any other way to do this, actually. Java is designed to be platform-independent, so almost all of its methods will give you the same results on a big-endian or little-endian machine.

node.contents: It's not a lib, it's a built-in class. You wouldn't get far in Java without them. In fact you wouldn't get anywhere without them. If they don't like your answer, ask yourself this: do I really want for a company that asks such stupid questions?

node.contents: I take no credit for this, however you can try:

units.rawText: import java.nio.ByteOrder; if (ByteOrder.nativeOrder().equals(ByteOrder.BIG_ENDIAN)) { System.out.println("Big-endian"); } else { System.out.println("Little-endian"); }

elements.contents: public static void getEndian(){ int a = 0; // 0x0....01 int b = 1; //0x0..0,0.01,0..0,0..0 int combine = (b<<16) | a; System.out.println(combine); if(combine == 65536){ System.out.println("LittleEndian"); }else{ System.out.println("BigEndian"); } }

comments.text: // 0x0....01 int b = 1; //0x0..0,0.01,0..0,0..0 int combine = (b<<16) | a; System.out.println(combine); if(combine == 65536){ System.out.println("LittleEndian"); }else{ System.out.println("BigEndian"); } }
